headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to ITT Corporation's Fourth Quarter 2009 Investor Review and Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to Tom Scalera, Director of ITT Investor Relations. Tom, you may begin.
componenttext: Welcome to ITT Corporation's Fourth Quarter 2009 Investor Review and Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to Tom Scalera, Director of ITT Investor Relations. Tom, you may begin.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Les. Good morning, and welcome to ITT's Fourth Quarter 2009 Investor Review. Presenting this morning are Chairman and CEO, Steven Loranger; and Chief Financial Officer, Denise Ramos. I'd like to highlight that this morning's presentation, press
componenttext: Thank you, Les. Good morning, and welcome to ITT's Fourth Quarter 2009 Investor Review. Presenting this morning are Chairman and CEO, Steven Loranger; and Chief Financial Officer, Denise Ramos. I'd like to highlight that this morning's presentation, press release and reconciliations of GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures can be found on our website at itt.com/ir. As always, please note that any remarks we may make about future expectations, plans and prospects, as well as other circumstances that are in our Safe Harbor statement constitute forward-looking statements for purposes of the Safe Harbor provision. Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by these forward-looking statements as a result of various important factors including those discussed in our fourth quarter 2009 earnings press release and our filings with the SEC. And now, let me turn things over to Steve to begin the call.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you all for joining us today. 2009 was a year of triumph for ITT. And today extend for the hundreds of ITT employees who gladly joined us for this call, I want to personally thank you all of you and your teams for an exceptional pe
componenttext: Good morning, and thank you all for joining us today. 2009 was a year of triumph for ITT. And today extend for the hundreds of ITT employees who gladly joined us for this call, I want to personally thank you all of you and your teams for an exceptional performance and contribution in 2009. This was a year that our leadership and our 40,000 team members were challenged with volatile uncertainty, a year where swift decisions were required in the absence of clarity [ph], in the year where our customers were equally challenged and were not able to predict even what their needs were. Given this situation, ITT employees chose to win. We steadfastly advanced our strategy to continue to invest in our customer's vital growth areas and to invest in our own contribution to make the world better in safety, security, in vitality and in corporate citizenship. This unwavering commitment to our future goes not without a price.  There was a price we're willing to pay to enable ITT to now take advantage of our current opportunities. Winning in this new economy meant that we have not only be steady with our strategy investments, but to ensure that our future viability was sound with exceptional execution in overdriving cost reductions, essentially establishing new break even point for the company and by preserving our liquidity and protecting our balance sheet.This wasn't easy. 2009 was strategic [ph] for many of us. But we're now very energized because we did it all, exceeding our own expectations. What was most remarkable to me was that after all of our employees' hard work, we achieved our highest levels of employee's engagement scores ever, with marked increases in the midst of our most challenging task. Not only did we finish with best in class business results, ITT was broadly recognized externally for our corporate responsibility with many accolades: We are rated number 30 among the world's best companies by Newsweek's Green Ranking; we remained in the top 100 best corporate citizen by Corporate Responsibility Magazine; we are listed among the top 50 for employee diversity in engineering and IT professionals; we remained the top 10 military employer; and again, on the Dow Jones Sustainability Index; honored by the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations for our sustainability work in China; and then finally, from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce Corporate Stewardship Awards.So while this was our second best year ever in terms of business results, I believe it was our finest performance as a team. So I think it's worth capturing and recognizing some of our employees' terrific efforts in 2009, all of which was built on our strategic foundation and our esprit de corps as a company.In 2009, we focused on managing our supply chain, ensuring our cost inputs were synchronized with reductions in volume, and we drove cycle-time reductions to ensure that volatile changes in the flow of goods were matched with the appropriate levels of working capital. We performed extremely well operationally. And on top of that, we increased customer satisfaction in 40 engagements, as I mentioned, and we accelerated our long-term strategy.On customers. We aligned with customer's need, invested in new technologies, and we consolidated Motion & Flow Control value centers around some customer solutions. The proof of these advances were evident in our impressive list of significant contract wins in 2009. These included: The CREW 3.3 jamming program; the Japanese weather satellite; an Indian irrigation project; as well as a very large Brazilian oil and gas project; a new program on one of the world's largest desalination plants in Saudi; Ford Taurus, Escape and Focus component; and global railway in India and China.On cost. We repositioned our cost structure. We exceeded our original restructuring plan by investing in and executing a total of $178 million of restructuring actions since the fourth quarter of 2008, resulting in a very significant 10% reduction in our Commercial business workforce. We reduced our overall manufacturing footprint by 1 million square feet. We consolidated 10 locations, and we grew our low-cost region in manufacturing and sourcing presence by over 25% year-over-year. All of these decisions were difficult because of the impact on our employees. But they're also the right moves to position our company for the long term. We also implemented merit freezes and incentive pay reductions for all executives, while significantly reducing discretionary spending. On capital. We set a new free cash flow record of $1 billion in 2009. We've paid down $640 million of debt, and we termed down $1 billion of commercial paper. We acquired an energy-efficient circulator manufacturing with the Laing acquisition, which has greatly exceeded our expectations. During 2009, we dramatically improved our financial capacity, and despite our purposeful pause on acquisitions during 2009, today we have a robust pipeline of opportunities. On operations. We delivered over $500 million in gross productivity. The structural changes made to optimize our sourcing and these succeeding initiatives will provide lasting benefits. We also streamlined the oversight of our Fluid and Motion segments, and we plan for similar activity within the defense strategic realignment, which we are executing now.True leadership emerges from two challenges, and our 2009 execution further underscores how strong our leaders are in ITT. We did not sit back and wait for the downturn to end. We proactively attacked it with courage and focus. And as a result, we did end here a challenging 2009 as a much stronger company. So the progress we've made in advancing our strategy really positioned us for continued strong growth in the future.Turning to Slide 4. With the 2009, we ended our backs. Let's take a look at 2010's strategic priorities: Strategic execution, differentiated organic growth and portfolio alignment. We're confident that we will continue to leverage the ITT management system to deliver strong sales growth, improve productivity and solid free cash flow. Our recent investment in operations to excellence, growth initiatives and defense transformation will accelerate our progress.So given the strength of our business, my primary focus in 2010 will be our portfolio actions around the growing macro trends such as aging infrastructure, growing middle class, water needs and global security. We will pursue fluid adjacencies, emerging market opportunities, air traffic control and cyber security. We have the financial capacity to further this alignment, and we have the leadership teams that know how to invest, integrate and deliver.On Slide 5. Our Defense segment has been positioned to support our customer's emerging technology needs, while also growing and enhancing our ability to stake out new markets. We believe that this change will also allow ITT to achieve greater operating efficiencies and optimize our cost structure. Here's what the new segment, named ITT Defense and Information Solutions, looks like. Our Electronic Systems, Communication Systems and a portion of our Intelligence & Information Warfare units will combine to a $2.6 billion Electronic Systems division. This division will deliver advanced protection measures to help ITT customers defend their networks and disable enemy networks. Improved leveraging of technology will significantly advance our position in two programs like the JTRS, airborne-endowed [ph] electronic warfare and CREW 3.3 development, where the jamming, networking and communicating technologies are all integrated program elements.Our Space Systems and Night Vision units will combine to form Geospatial Systems. This new $1.2 billion value center will focus on next-generation energy that integrates space, airborne, ground and soldiers sensors into broader, coordinated systems. This combination will improve our competitiveness in the areas of digitally-enhanced night vision goggles, unmanned aerial vehicles and integrated intelligence surveillance and reconnaissance solutions.Our Advanced Engineering & Sciences and our systems units were combined with part of Intelligent & Information Warfare to form Information Systems. This new $2.5 billion value center focus will be our network decision solution by combining large systems operations with the sophisticated techniques in information integration and protection. With powerful combination, we'll advance opportunities in the FAA's Next Generation air traffic management solutions, NASA programs and national intelligence networks as well as cyber security. We are very, very pleased with this initiative to substantially reposition our definitive Information Solutions business for the future. And now, Denise will review the business.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. So like Steve, I am very proud of our 2009 financial performances. Now let's take a closer look at some of the specific results.In the fourth quarter and for the full year, we delivered organic revenue performances that were down only 5%, c
componenttext: Thanks, Steve. So like Steve, I am very proud of our 2009 financial performances. Now let's take a closer look at some of the specific results.In the fourth quarter and for the full year, we delivered organic revenue performances that were down only 5%, compared to the prior year. The enduring nature of the demand for our products and our strong execution helped generate these solid results even in difficult market conditions. Our adjusted EPS in the fourth quarter of $0.97 was 18% higher than the prior year due to the benefits from our productivity initiatives, prior restructuring actions and lower restructuring and realignment cost that more than offset lower volumes and cost increases. For the full year, our adjusted EPS of $3.78 was down only 6%. And let me make an observation here. If you adjust for what I'll call non-operating items, both favorable and unfavorable, items such as FX, pension, restructuring and acquisitions, our 2009 operating EPS is down only 2% to 2008. Not many peers were able to deliver that kind of performance in 2009. Compared to the increased guidance mid-point that we just provided you on the guidance call on December 18, our adjusted 2009 EPS was $0.05 stronger. And that was due to slightly improved operating performances and lower non-operating expenses, partially offset by increased restructuring actions. Organic orders improved 3% compared to the prior year, and that was on strength in many of our key end markets, while difficult compared remains in industrial, commercial and aerospace. Sequential order growth of 25% reflected strength of Defense and positive performances at both Fluid and Motion. We are confident in our 2010 revenue forecasts, and our recent order trends and quoting activity is starting to pick up in some of the longer-cycle businesses. So not only did we deliver our best-in-class EPS performance in 2009, but we also greatly improved our financial position. Turn to Slide 7. In 2009, we generated a record $1.1 billion in free cash flow, excluding the after-tax impact of a $100 million discretionary pension contribution that we made in the fourth quarter. This free cash flow performance was 22% better than the prior year, and it reflected a 146% conversion of continuing net income adjusted for non-cash special items. Our working capital, as a percent of sales, improved 70 basis points to 12.4%. And our net-debt-to-net-capital ratio declined from 27.9% at the beginning of the year to just 7% at the end of 2009. In addition, we have nearly exited the short-term commercial paper market, and we do have over $1.2 billion in cash. Now let's turn to Fluid Technology's fourth quarter results that's on Slide 8. Fluid delivered a solid Q4 that was actually better than our internal expectations due to improved top-line performances. The 13% organic revenue decline reflected continued strength in municipal markets that was offset by anticipated declines in industrial and commercial markets. Productivity gained momentum all year at Fluid and has repeatedly helped to mitigate lower volume and cost increases.Organic orders in the quarter were down 2%, but they were ahead of expectations. Front order activity was seen in the municipal treatment in transport, mining and oil and gas markets. The strength was more than offset by weaker global commercial and North American industrial orders. Sequential orders were slightly positive, and leading indicators on industrial activities have turned more favorable recently. For example, sequential organic orders at industrial process decreased 6%, and the book-to-bill rate in the quarter was 1.03. Also in the quarter, Fluid won a significant $20 million oil and gas contract in Brazil and a $7 million desalination project in Saudi Arabia. So with this latest win in Saudi Arabia, ITT now has products in three of the five largest desalinating facilities in the world. A view of the Motion Flow controls, our fourth quarter results on Slide 9. Motion revenue was down only 1% organically due to aerospace and general industrial weakness that was nearly offset by strong results in the automotive, rail, beverage and marine markets. In all of these segments, our competitive advantages drove market share gains during the downturn. And let's keep in mind that these share gains will be produced on our much more efficient manufacturing platform going forward.Operating margins improved 610 basis points in total and 230 basis points operationally compared to the prior year. This performance does reflect both the lower restructuring cost in the quarter and the aggregate benefit of two years of restructuring and realignment going back to 2008 but now total $84 million.Organic orders improved 7% with big gains at flow control and motion technology. We are taking share in food and beverage markets. We are winning significant global platforms in auto and rail. And we are seeing some general signs of stability in the connectors and general industrial markets. We do expect that aerospace will remain under pressure, but on the whole, Motion & Flow Control has clearly emerged from this past downturn as a leaner, more competitively-focused collection of growing businesses.Let's turn to Defense on Slide 10. The slight organic revenue decline in the quarter was consistent with our latest expectations. Service growth was strong with increased activity on a number of different contracts, including Maxwell Air Force Base and the FAA Next Generation air traffic control program, ADS-B. International Night Vision grew significantly in the fourth quarter, and we expect continued strength into 2010. Increases in airborne electronic warfare were partially offset -- our lower ground electronic warfare, and SINCGARS volumes were down versus a strong prior year. Organic order growth of 5% brought our year-end defense backlog to $5.2 billion, generally flat the prior-year levels with little change in the mix of products and services. New order growth reflected anticipated replenishments of service contract fundings and a significant Japanese weather satellite order that more than offset lower ground electronic warfare orders.Productivity continued to be strong with 120 basis points of operational improvement in the quarter. So this strong performance pushed the full year defense margins up to a record 12.3%. Our recently announced Defense strategic realignment, coupled with the continuation of our productivity actions, will nicely benefit long-term Defense segment margins.Now let's turn to Slide 11 and talk about the 2010 guidance. So our strong Q4 performance has set us up very nicely on moving into 2010. Further stabilization in key end markets plus expanded productivity actions and increased confidence in our execution of these actions have contributed to our decision to increase our 2010 EPS guidance by $0.05 to $3.90 to $4.10. Now let me point out that our new 2010 EPS range is already back in line with our pre-economic downturn 2008 adjusted EPS, a remarkable accomplishment in a relatively short period of time. Sentimentally, our revenue guidance remained unchanged from the December outlook call. We are still projecting organic growth revenue growth in the 2% range, but future indicators have improved since December, increasing our overall confidence level.Regarding the key assumptions from the outlook call. 2010 pension expense will be a little higher due to a 6% discount rate for our U.S. salary plan. But this expense increase will be offset by a lower tax rate in the 30% to 30.5% range. The strategic Defense realignment that we announced on January 5 will cause our total restructuring expense to increase to $55 million to $65 million. But keep in mind that this increased expense versus prior guidance is expected to be fully offset in 2010 by increased restructuring savings.For the first quarter of 2010, we are projecting EPS in the $0.73 to $0.75 range. At the mid-point, this represents the 3% improvement compared to the prior year. The first quarter of 2010 results include higher restructuring expenses associated with the Defense realignment. Despite improvement in both Commercial segment, first quarter revenues are expected to be down 1%, but that's due to a 7% decline in expense that reflects timing of radio and jammer shipments. Keep in mind that we expect full year 2010 Defense revenues to increase 3% to 4%, and incremental service contracts and international product activity are projected for the second half of 2010. So now with that overview, let me turn things over to Tom to begin the Q&A.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from John Inch of Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from John Inch of Merrill Lynch.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I'm curious, did your commercial orders strengthened sequentially in the fourth quarter kind of on a month-by-month basis? And has this actually continued in January?
componenttext: So I'm curious, did your commercial orders strengthened sequentially in the fourth quarter kind of on a month-by-month basis? And has this actually continued in January?

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, when you look at the orders, there's some seasonality when you look at it on a month-to-month basis. So it's really hard there to talk about that even though when I look at Fluid Technology, the month of December was higher than the month of Nov
componenttext: Actually, when you look at the orders, there's some seasonality when you look at it on a month-to-month basis. So it's really hard there to talk about that even though when I look at Fluid Technology, the month of December was higher than the month of November. But again, you have to be careful because of the seasonality. When I look at it on a sequential basis quarter to quarter, my Fluid Technology is up 1%, Motion & Flow is up 2%. What's interesting when you look and you delve down into the various end markets, some of the end market that we've had challenges with, in terms of IP and RPW and our Connectors business in Motion & Flow, we actually saw decent sequential order growth. So that was encouraging for us.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Denise, what's the pricing look like on the new orders and activity that you're receiving today? How competitive is this stuff? And do you think your profitability holds based on what you got in backlog?
componenttext: And Denise, what's the pricing look like on the new orders and activity that you're receiving today? How competitive is this stuff? And do you think your profitability holds based on what you got in backlog?

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, when we look at pricing, we think about pricing in Q4. There was very minimal price impact that we saw. And then when we think about 2010, and we think about pricing in our Commercial segment, a little bit of price impact, little bit on the IT side w
componenttext: Yes, when we look at pricing, we think about pricing in Q4. There was very minimal price impact that we saw. And then when we think about 2010, and we think about pricing in our Commercial segment, a little bit of price impact, little bit on the IT side we've seen on from project [ph] business. But overall, there is really nothing that's going to be largely significant on the commercial side of our business.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, I just want to add that given that we did a program into our plan, some pricing pressure with respect to that. So hopefully we'll be on a short [ph] throughout the year.
componenttext: John, I just want to add that given that we did a program into our plan, some pricing pressure with respect to that. So hopefully we'll be on a short [ph] throughout the year.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you just remind us? I mean, some companies have talked about a favorable spread benefits like diminishing from 2009 to 2010. Did you guys have a favorable spread benefit in terms of your raw material cost? And is that presenting a bit of a headwind in
componenttext: Can you just remind us? I mean, some companies have talked about a favorable spread benefits like diminishing from 2009 to 2010. Did you guys have a favorable spread benefit in terms of your raw material cost? And is that presenting a bit of a headwind in 2009 or 2010? Or is not that material [ph]?

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, when I look at 2010, John, and I look at the full year versus 2009, we are seeing and projecting cost increases on the raw material side, about 3.5% to about 4.5%. And then you're going to have general inflation on your other cost above that. When I
componenttext: Well, when I look at 2010, John, and I look at the full year versus 2009, we are seeing and projecting cost increases on the raw material side, about 3.5% to about 4.5%. And then you're going to have general inflation on your other cost above that. When I compare that to what we're achieving on our supply chain initiatives and some of the productivity actions that we have with that, we are more than offsetting that or we expect to more than offset that in 2010. So we should see some favorability associated with that because of the strong productivity that we drive.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Would you ever consider selling pieces of your Defense business? And post this re-organization, would that make a partial sale theoretically easier or theoretically more difficult?
componenttext: Would you ever consider selling pieces of your Defense business? And post this re-organization, would that make a partial sale theoretically easier or theoretically more difficult?

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, John, I think we look at our portfolio strategically in terms of more market positions and the attractiveness of markets. In all, we actually have not looked specifically at the point that you're making. Maybe what we want to do right now is get thr
componenttext: Well, John, I think we look at our portfolio strategically in terms of more market positions and the attractiveness of markets. In all, we actually have not looked specifically at the point that you're making. Maybe what we want to do right now is get through the overall Defense transformation and get the new leadership teams comprising sort of a new, more holistic strategy in our military platforms and ensure at that point that we've got the right combination of businesses. So when we view that from time to time, and if something doesn't get, leading us to our future strategy, we're sure to point and communicate that. At this point in time, we're busy with the Defense transformation and making a goal out of it.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Shannon O'Callaghan of Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Shannon O'Callaghan of Barclays.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: But in terms of the Defense re-org expenses and savings, you mentioned some pressure in the first quarter. I mean, can you give us a feel of how those kind of flow out quarterly through the year? And then what kind of savings are you expecting in '11 plus
componenttext: But in terms of the Defense re-org expenses and savings, you mentioned some pressure in the first quarter. I mean, can you give us a feel of how those kind of flow out quarterly through the year? And then what kind of savings are you expecting in '11 plus?

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So we're detailing a lot of that right now. What we've got in our numbers here is, we do know that the restructuring expense will be weighted into the first half of this year. So we will see it in Q1 and Q2. The benefit associated with that will be more i
componenttext: So we're detailing a lot of that right now. What we've got in our numbers here is, we do know that the restructuring expense will be weighted into the first half of this year. So we will see it in Q1 and Q2. The benefit associated with that will be more in the back half of the year. So when we look in total for the full year, when we announced the Defense re-organization, what we said is that the cost associated with restructuring will be offset by the savings that we're expecting to see in 2010. But you're going to see it sequence differently as you go throughout the quarters because where the expenses versus where the productivity is. In terms of the overall benefit that we're going to see with that, we're still detailing it. But we would expect that, that will help us with the long-term margin that we're going to be forecasting going out into the future. So again, we're still detailing that out, but we would expect to see some positive that's flowing through to our margins.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the radio and jammer timing you mentioned, I mean, it's weak in 1Q. What's driving that? And does it all coming in 2Q or is this second half loaded or how does it come out from there?
componenttext: Okay. And then the radio and jammer timing you mentioned, I mean, it's weak in 1Q. What's driving that? And does it all coming in 2Q or is this second half loaded or how does it come out from there?

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, on a year-over-year basis, we have strong pre-delivery in the first quarter of '09. And again, that has to do with just the requirement as to the customer requirement associated with that and the surge in Afghanistan. So you did see a strong deliver
componenttext: Well, on a year-over-year basis, we have strong pre-delivery in the first quarter of '09. And again, that has to do with just the requirement as to the customer requirement associated with that and the surge in Afghanistan. So you did see a strong delivery that grew in Q1 of '09. With that, on a quarterly foot for Defense for this year, we're seeing more of our jammer delivery taking place in second quarter and third quarter, and then through the rest of the year than we're seeing in Q1. So that is impacting defense in Q1.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jim Lucas of Janney Montgomery Scott.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jim Lucas of Janney Montgomery Scott.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: With regards to the restructuring savings carryover from 2009, how much did you book in '09 versus carrying over to 2010?
componenttext: With regards to the restructuring savings carryover from 2009, how much did you book in '09 versus carrying over to 2010?

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So let me phrase this. In 2010, the carryover from the actions that we're taking in 2009, the incremental benefit is about $40 million to $45 million.
componenttext: So let me phrase this. In 2010, the carryover from the actions that we're taking in 2009, the incremental benefit is about $40 million to $45 million.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the Fluid side, obviously residential is stabilizing, commercial, industrial still some pressure. Within the municipal, you saw some good growth on the backlog. Are you beginning to see any orders flowing in from stimulus-related funds?
componenttext: On the Fluid side, obviously residential is stabilizing, commercial, industrial still some pressure. Within the municipal, you saw some good growth on the backlog. Are you beginning to see any orders flowing in from stimulus-related funds?

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. It be minor in nature. We expect somewhere in the order of $20 million coming in from stimulus funds this year. We built that into our plan. So we are seeing it [ph] regions we discussed last year, it's been relatively slow. And it's been posit
componenttext: Well, yes. It be minor in nature. We expect somewhere in the order of $20 million coming in from stimulus funds this year. We built that into our plan. So we are seeing it [ph] regions we discussed last year, it's been relatively slow. And it's been positive for us. We are well positioned to play with the budgets when they withdraw [ph], but it's not a significant amount for us.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And finally, with regards to capital allocation strategy, for the last couple of quarters, you highlighted air traffic control and cybersecurity as the areas that you're looking in addition to Water, that's been out there for some time, where you've had a
componenttext: And finally, with regards to capital allocation strategy, for the last couple of quarters, you highlighted air traffic control and cybersecurity as the areas that you're looking in addition to Water, that's been out there for some time, where you've had a lot of resources committed. Within the air traffic and cyber, I mean, are there larger properties out there or is it more technology, smaller in size? And then absent the acquisition strategy, could you give us an update of where you stand with regards to your share repurchase program?

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jim, on the first question, with air traffic management as well as cyber, are enormous growing businesses today. So the answer is yes. With respect to acquisition opportunity, they do fall in a complete range of small technology niches to very, very large
componenttext: Jim, on the first question, with air traffic management as well as cyber, are enormous growing businesses today. So the answer is yes. With respect to acquisition opportunity, they do fall in a complete range of small technology niches to very, very large, billion-dollar-plus networking solutions in data processing logistics companies. So we do again -- and the same is true for cyber. So we do have a broad array of acquisition opportunities there. And to the point in question, as far as our capital allocation goes, we're going to continue to drive the air traffic management, cyber and Fluid Technology adjacent with our primary strategy. We have other activities around the Rail and around aerospace and around other components of our business. But I think you're correct by saying those three really form the basis of our near-term focus. Having said that, in this environment as I mentioned, we do have a robust acquisition pipeline following the intentional pause that we put on it to preserve liquidity through the 2009 time period. So we're not anticipating any change in our share buyback, which is to say, that's on pause. Right now, we plan on deploying our cash responsibly of course, with primarily in the acquisition area.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jeff Sprague of Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jeff Sprague of Citigroup.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, first of all on productivity, obviously the $500 million is a big number. I just wonder if you could give us a little bit of insight other than the kind of sensor/headcount-type things, but what you've done to kind of maybe change the culture or dr
componenttext: Steve, first of all on productivity, obviously the $500 million is a big number. I just wonder if you could give us a little bit of insight other than the kind of sensor/headcount-type things, but what you've done to kind of maybe change the culture or drive the business differently? Is it supply chain? Is it sourcing? Are there things here that are durable, that you think you can build upon from here?

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mentioned in my opening comments that we paid a price for our performance and quite frankly, that was one of them. We did in fact, as a leadership team, going after a lot higher levels of productivity than we had before. So it was a combination of event
componenttext: I mentioned in my opening comments that we paid a price for our performance and quite frankly, that was one of them. We did in fact, as a leadership team, going after a lot higher levels of productivity than we had before. So it was a combination of events that were out there and some of it was classic, if you will, in the sense that we were driving our traditional, value-based needs of save more, Kaizen [ph] culture. But we took this opportunity to be much more substantial, which was a very significant challenge, which was well done by the team, to actually close, to just get out there in the physical closing of a number of facilities, the moving of our manufacturing footprint more aggressively low-cost. We did spectacular progress last year in India, in China, in Poland and in the Czech Republic, as well as in Mexico in that regard. So a lot of that was really an acceleration of low-cost footprint. Munish Nanda and his team in operations achieved a remarkable increase in transitioning the global strategic sourcing to achieve our highest level of low-cost region sourcing, which is another source of material cost savings about the [ph] commodities and in finished goods. As I mentioned, I think we're in the 25% range. The cultural change was two-part, Jeff, and we really adopted it to the leadership team. What we wanted do was get the leadership mindset changed around. In this new economy, we are going to have to -- in a sustainably -- go after higher levels of product synergy as a way of life. Knowing that there was going to be more maturity in the top line coming out of this economic recession, we wanted to be able to index the premier earnings per share performance, which means that we need to get more productivity. So we have embarked on looking in new areas. First of all, as part of our vision is that customers are central in everything we do and what we mean by that is, we'll be taking all of our macro processes and driving structural productivity to streamline those macro customer processes, delivering order-entry responsiveness, technology speed to the market and so forth. Colin Sabol and Joe Vesey and his team were driving a very significant re-admission [ph] we call value-based customer excellence. And we have, as you know, several hundred million and an outstanding global footprint through our distribution capabilities, primarily our commercial businesses. And Joe and Colin and his team are really driving some contemporary processes both in terms of technology and in terms of customer focus that will provide a whole other level of productivity. So those are just some of the examples that clearly, the leadership team mindset shift that we identified is all about going after very meaningful, sustaining productivity. All the while knowing that that's ultimately get accrued, the competitive advantages and allow us to move in premier So as far as I'm concerned, I've been seeing for a long time that we have a lot of productivity opportunities in this company. They're getting harder to get, we have sensed that we got to focus on structural macro process and that's exactly what we're doing;;.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kind of maybe along those lines, as Denise indicated, the restructuring cost in Defense versus savings is a wash in '10, but should set you up for structural benefit beyond that. Just stepping back from that from a little bit bigger picture, obviously the
componenttext: Kind of maybe along those lines, as Denise indicated, the restructuring cost in Defense versus savings is a wash in '10, but should set you up for structural benefit beyond that. Just stepping back from that from a little bit bigger picture, obviously the Defense margins are going to be mix related and we're all going to have to try to figure that out on our own to some degree. I'm just kind of curious, relative to your customer's expectation about what the suppliers have earned, your confidence level to maintain Defense margins kind of in the call it low teens with an upside bias even.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So Jeffrey, Denise mentioned, this year is extensive matching benefit from the transformation. We're going to see sustaining benefits, we're still detailing it, but in the $80 million range, win out in years as a result of this transformation. And what we
componenttext: So Jeffrey, Denise mentioned, this year is extensive matching benefit from the transformation. We're going to see sustaining benefits, we're still detailing it, but in the $80 million range, win out in years as a result of this transformation. And what we're doing is just like we did in commercial, a lot of structural integration and leadership process improvement that I just mentioned. But having said that, the Defense environment really, in our view, is not changing despite acquisition reform initiatives. And that environment's still going to need their suppliers to earn the appropriate amount. Remember, a lot of the cost-plus business is cost-negotiated profit levels on a cost-justified basis. So a lot of transparency in that and that tends to be more operating margin. However, on the fixed price, pre-enterprise business management prevails in the Defense business and I think that I continue to see our ability to make margin in this business. So we're going to see some definite operating margin benefit improvement as a result of these activities. But however, we'll be impacted as Denise mentioned, by pension. Now, some amount of that pension is ultimately covered in retired senior rates, but quite frankly, it had not been for this pension, you would've seen a lot stronger margins in Defense for 2010. But even in the high 11s, in the low teens, that's exactly what we said we were going to be driving and Dave and his team are committed to improve the business metrics.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010

componenttext: Do you sell, and I don't know how you would scale this, obviously it depends on the size of the plant and gallons of processing per day or hour, but when you look at kind of the ITT portfolio and maybe what I'd call your natural entitlement in one of these plants, how would you say the penetration rate is going there? And has there been positive change, in other words, higher penetration rate or lower penetration rate?

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, I think that question deserves a lot longer discussion. We'll be glad to go over that with you because there's a lot of pieces to it. We played in these fairly prominently in terms of water transport pumps and water pressure boosters. We also have a
componenttext: Jeff, I think that question deserves a lot longer discussion. We'll be glad to go over that with you because there's a lot of pieces to it. We played in these fairly prominently in terms of water transport pumps and water pressure boosters. We also have a lot of pre-treatment capability with rough filtration, the Leopold business. And of course, we also have reverse osmosis. In terms of our entitlement, again I don't know the numbers but we're extremely strong with pumps and rough filtration. Most of our reverse osmosis technology generally tends to be a smaller scale business. However at this point, we are proud in fact that we are providing a wide range of all these technology on three of the five largest facilities in the world. So that's about all I know right now, Jeff, and I think your question will need some more research and I'll see if we can give you a better answer.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010

componenttext: And Steve, in your opening comments about portfolio alignment, you did say that you'd be interested in pursuing some adjacencies in Fluid. And as you just kind of recapped your positioning today in Water, I think you're still more of a pump-centric company. You've got technologies like UV and ozone. But what do you consider to be the attractive adjacencies? Are they more geographic or are they sort of niche technologies like you've done with variable speed drives?

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: They're both, Deane, and if the world's largest pump manufacturer work through the fact that 70% of the revenue opportunities is within the water drill and pumps. So let's not forget if any [indiscernible] we will be continuing to withstand our pump techn
componenttext: They're both, Deane, and if the world's largest pump manufacturer work through the fact that 70% of the revenue opportunities is within the water drill and pumps. So let's not forget if any [indiscernible] we will be continuing to withstand our pump technology organically and needed [ph] standards in globally on an inorganic basis. We are a broad supplier of other technology as you know, but to specifically answer your questions, there are three technologies that we really think, beyond pumps, are the areas we want to drive. In medical testing and instrumentation is an area that we already have some capability in throughout our business, but it's a business we'd like to grow and there's obviously some opportunities there. The Water is another area. Again, we already have several hundred million dollars in Water business buried, for the most part in our www franchise and this is a growing valuable space, which we can add-on to, both geographically and bolt-on acquisitions. And then finally in treatment, the areas of treatment that we like to grow in have to do with the membrane, ultra- and micro-filtration membrane participation and some opportunities there. So those are the three areas. In the global areas, except the emerging markets, Gretchen and her team have been aggressive in positioning our marketing and our manufacturing, operational capabilities in these emerging markets. And to the extent that we could sometimes buy in small companies that represent footprints on getting in these emerging markets is very, very attractive. And I'm pleased to say, in every dimension I just mentioned, we have an active pipeline.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if there are a lot of positives and negatives out of the budget news this week. And obviously, you're not sort of focusing on that. But I'm just wondering from a longer-term perspective, if there was anything in there that made you more opti
componenttext: I'm wondering if there are a lot of positives and negatives out of the budget news this week. And obviously, you're not sort of focusing on that. But I'm just wondering from a longer-term perspective, if there was anything in there that made you more optimistic or made you more cautious about any of the programs that -- where some of those pieces of the puzzle may have moved there based on the news this week.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: The request answered to the most recent released Presidential budget that we're extremely pleased with it. It does represent an upside to our thinking. We're not totally surprised because we do understand the real nature of the Defense requirements. But h
componenttext: The request answered to the most recent released Presidential budget that we're extremely pleased with it. It does represent an upside to our thinking. We're not totally surprised because we do understand the real nature of the Defense requirements. But here's for everyone's background if you're not familiar, we were looking at a $660 billion fiscal year '10 budget. And even though the new administration said they were not going to put in an additional FY '10 supplemental, he did it easily and he upped it by $33 billion dollars with the FY '10 finishing yet up over FY '09. And even though the administration likewise said that there was no way that the we're going to support defense budget increases, in fact they were very aggressive about saying they didn't see defense budget decrease into FY '11. What President Obama came out with this week was a yet 11.2% percent increase to the top line up now to a proposed $708 billion for the FY '11. This was actually not surprising. In fact, I was able, fortunately, two weeks ago to personally meet Secretary of Defense Robert Gates and he clearly articulated that he maintained the expectation that this local budget that was going to the prevail simply because of the needs which you all know about, in terms of force projection and vital recharge with our defense units. So if you all know that story, I think what you're seeing right now, is from a business piece, a positive affirmation from the administration that they also agree that we need to have a very, very strong defense as part of our overall national agenda. Specifically again, what we've seen is in the IED jamming area, there are a number of things that are still being retailed with respect to downstream competition opportunities with the CREW 2.1 series, as well as potential competitions on existing vehicles. We see some -- there was a package and very nice opportunities. There was a third opportunity for advancing competition with the Marine Corps and JIVE node, which is the IED office. Actually, they're all over a billion dollar budget increase. So that all needs to be detailed, but it's an upside for ITT. We saw a strong support with the increase in the nightvision budget and so that should enable some opportunity for us. And the same guys, while it's small but it's a validated move with a place over in there and the advanced active communication program budget will go up in the 6% to 7% range. So you add all that up and again, the details need to be sorted out and this is just the President's budget. There's an ongoing process to detail this. But we fundamentally think it was a positive for us. The other thing that I want to mention on this was at non-Defense, but the major initiative force, of course, is the ADS-B next-generation air traffic control technology for the FAA. And the FAA's budget went up about 25% over $1 billion in this area, underscoring the opportunity we've been working on with the next generation or the next programs after ADS-B, Datacom, SE 2020 and so forth. So what that means is the administration has realized that a strong component of driving new economic efficiencies is going to be getting a contemporary air traffic control system and they want to speed it up. So all in all, we've seen it as a slight positive for us.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the translation, I'm wondering about it. I think you had said in December on a sort of very preliminary basis, you felt like 2011, the Defense business could be, I think the phrase you used was, up slightly but I don't want to put words in your mo
componenttext: I guess the translation, I'm wondering about it. I think you had said in December on a sort of very preliminary basis, you felt like 2011, the Defense business could be, I think the phrase you used was, up slightly but I don't want to put words in your mouth. And obviously  here, with the 2011 budget indications and your commentary here, it sounds like maybe there's some upside to that. I guess within that context though, it sounds like maybe some of the upside comes from the product side of the house, which I'm wondering as we go back to parse through all the mix issues, it doesn't have some positive margin implications. How would you comment on those two thoughts?

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're on the right tack. We're giving you a long-range Defense budget, that's why we said we were pleased but not surprised with this budget because, we have been planning for something like this. We also had been forecasting the fact that our defense te
componenttext: You're on the right tack. We're giving you a long-range Defense budget, that's why we said we were pleased but not surprised with this budget because, we have been planning for something like this. We also had been forecasting the fact that our defense teams have consistently outperformed the market, outperformed the defense budget with some terrific technology and some -- it's very good program in the Internet [ph]. And so when we gave you a slight up, what we were thinking of at that time is we're going to withstand some of these adjacencies. We've been talking about like the air traffic management, like some of the NASA surveillance, like some of the international programs. So remember, compared to where we were, say five years ago, when we were almost exclusive with the Department of Defense, we today have almost 25% of our Defense businesses is what you would call non-DOD. But that's just saying that building -- our $1.5 billion business space outside of our core business. So here's the strategy that we've been talking about. Yes, it's working and we think the absolute of some of our revenue shares going to come from. On the margin side, there's going to be two forces at play. One is going to be the fact that's there's going to be intense competition for more defense contractors, as you can expect. But we would also get some benefits from this reorganization. And so hopefully, that'll enable us to shore up our margins through this process.

componenttext: I would say that it was in that range. We're still detailing it. So we need to consider offset in terms of mix and volume and problematics that normally occur. But yes, we're expecting to get substantial benefits from the reorganization of Defense.

componenttext: What we're expecting to see is we're expecting to see that a little bit more heavily weighted in the second half versus the first half. And the key programs there would be some international sales with SINCGARS. And when we look at our jamming platform and our CREW devices, we expect that, that point will be in the back half of the year versus the first half of the year. So those are basically the two main factors that drive the back half versus the first half. We also will see more service revenues in the back half of the year than we see in the first half of the year and part of that will be associated with LOGCAP.

componenttext: Fluid margins into 2010, what we're expecting for Fluid margins is we are expecting to see a nice improvement in fluid margins when we look at 2010. Now you've got to be careful with the restructuring expenses and pension expenses. So when we look at from what I would call an operating performance for Fluid, we are expecting their margins to be up about 40 to 50 basis points year-over-year.

componenttext: Some of it is just the fact of what's been happening from a revenue standpoint. And we continue to migrate more of our receivables and our payables activity into tiered services. And so that also helps us to be able to drive down those balances.

componenttext: And the $20 million that you called out as the stimulus assumption for 2010, is that your orders and shipment presumption? headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, we understand your question. We used [ph] appropriate number. Yes, I don't think we would say that there's a $500 million opportunity in pumps and levers. We're seeing comparisons that [indiscernible] on that one. But this stimulus money has been ve
componenttext: Mike, we understand your question. We used [ph] appropriate number. Yes, I don't think we would say that there's a $500 million opportunity in pumps and levers. We're seeing comparisons that [indiscernible] on that one. But this stimulus money has been very, very small to come out. And our teams in our business that continue to work out, but we think it's a right number to be telling on. We get more, we'd certainly look.

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Some of these large projects that Tom alluded to. The pricing on those, given the globals excess capacity, could you just give us a sense of where pricing is and where you expect it to head, at least this year on some of these largest Water & Wastewater p
componenttext: Some of these large projects that Tom alluded to. The pricing on those, given the globals excess capacity, could you just give us a sense of where pricing is and where you expect it to head, at least this year on some of these largest Water & Wastewater projects?

headline: ITT Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think we have an index on pricing because these projects have tended to be very unique. Right now, we are not seeing any specific trends in those pricing, although we certainly are expecting a little [ph] pricing environment means [ph]. Let me jus
componenttext: I don't think we have an index on pricing because these projects have tended to be very unique. Right now, we are not seeing any specific trends in those pricing, although we certainly are expecting a little [ph] pricing environment means [ph]. Let me just take this moment to wrap up with all of you. First of all, as I mentioned in my opening comments, it's an important complement of our corporate citizenship strategy to make sure we give back to society in a meaningful way and I want to give you an update on our efforts in Haiti. Our approach to disaster response is very broad and multi-faceted and encompasses not only direct financial support, but also the contribution of our talented staff, products and services in both water treatment and emergency communications. Within days of the earthquake, ITT employees were on the ground and even provided emergency communications and disaster relief. We shipped five portable water treatment units, eight reverse osmosis units that are going to supply enough water to support 200,000 people. ITT employees are also making a significant direct financial contribution to the relief. And today, ITT's employee donations and ITT matching fund exceed more than $430,000. So I'll just highlight that these contributions, as well as other ones relate to ITT Water market offer substantial benefit to society and makes us all so proud about working here. So I'm going to use this an opportunity and see if this combination of who we are, our values-based work environment and our business strategy that enable us continued success. This roll bounce portfolio was the foundation of the results during 2009. And we're very proud of our teams around the globe for delivering on these commitments and as was highlighted during the call, some very significant increases in cost-side, cash-side productivity. We took important steps to position the company by advancing these productivity initiatives and increasing our strategic investment and generating strong free cash flow. So we believe that it is our innovation and essential focus with our products and services that position us to continue to grow well in the future, certainly at or above the markets we serve. We are very confident in our growth outlook for 2010. We got exceptional visibility of orders in our core markets and we've positive in winning [ph] achievements in our little [ph] cycle businesses. And more importantly, we think we've got the right leaders, strategy and resources in place to generate continued premier performance. We're confident in our ability to deliver 2010 as we've committed. I want to thank you all for joining us and we're off to a good start for the year.
